DOC.HEAD: Peru Resumes Joint Drug-Fighting Efforts With United States
Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to FIX name of agency to Drug Enforcement Administration
DOC.TEXT: Peru has decided to resume joint anti-drug operations with the United States, a week after the Peruvian leader halted the activity to protest the invasion of Panama, the Justice Department said Wednesday. David Runkel, a department spokesman, said the ``reconstituted joint efforts in Peru'' between Drug Enforcement Administration and Peruvian officials began Tuesday. The Peruvian Embassy said joint operations resumed because ``the fight against drugs is so important.'' ' The anti-drug operations ceased after the U.S. invasion of Panama on Dec. 20. Peruvian officials called the invasion an ``outrage against Latin America.'' At the time, Peruvian President Alan Garcia said he would boycott the Feb. 15 drug summit that is to be held in Colombia. President Bush plans to attend. An embassy official, speaking on condition he remain anonymous, said he didn't know whether Garcia had changed his mind and would attend. Bush, talking to reporters as he began a vacation in Texas Wednesday, said, ``I would hope that Garcia would change his mind.'' He said that ``inasmuch as Peru is an Andean country and this is an Andean summit with the United States participating, trying to help them, I would think it would be lessened _ you know, less inclusive, obviously _ but I'd think that there are ways to continue to help Peru in this fight.'' The Peruvian embassy official said Peruvian officials intend to send representatives to a meeting in Bolivia on Jan. 10 at which officials from Bogota, Quito and Lima will coordinate strategy for the drug summit. The United States finances a number of joint operations aimed at wiping out the drug trade from Peru. They include anti-drug patrols in the Upper Huallaga Valley where most of the Peruvian coca leaf is derived. Cocaine is derived from coca. DEA agents also work on joint paramilitary operations with the Peruvians and help them with investigations, including locating drug traffickers.
